Study revealed that miR-145-5p is downregulated in psoriatic lesional skin and that MLK3 is a direct target of miR-145-5p. Overexpression of miR-145-5p in normal human epidermal keratinocytes (NHEKs) suppressed cell proliferation and secretion of chemokines. In contrast, silencing miR-145-5p promoted NHEK proliferation and increased chemokine secretion.

Study identified that genetic loss/inhibition of a MLK3, increases CD8+ T cell cytotoxicity via inhibition of a prolyl isomerase, Ppia, and nuclear translocation of NFATc1. The MLK3 inhibitor increased the tumor infiltration of cytotoxic T cells in an immune-competent mouse model of breast cancer and increased the cytotoxic T cell population in pan T cells isolated from breast cancer patients with metastatic disease.

summary: The protein encoded by this gene is a member of the serine/threonine kinase family. This kinase contains a SH3 domain and a leucine zipper-basic motif. This kinase preferentially activates MAPK8/JNK kinase, and functions as a positive regulator of JNK signaling pathway. This kinase can directly phosphorylate, and activates IkappaB kinase alpha and beta, and is found to be involved in the transcription activity of NF-kappaB mediated by Rho family GTPases and CDC42. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
